G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: General Laws c. 186, § 14 provides, in relevant part, that a landlord shall not “directly or indirectly interfere with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant.” A landlord who violates this covenant is liable for actual and consequential damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater, together with costs and reasonable attorneys’ fees.

G.L. c. 218, \u00a7\u00a7 1, 19, and 19A.proposition: Jurisdiction and venue are proper in the Boston Municipal Court pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §§ 1, 19, and 19A because the Premises are located in Boston (Dorchester neighborhood) and the events giving rise to this action occurred within this Court’s territorial jurisdiction.

105 C.M.R. 410.201 (formerly 410.200) (S.proposition: Massachusetts regulations require that, during the heating season (September 15 through June 15), the temperature in a dwelling unit must be at least 68°F between 7:00 a.m. and 11:00 p.m., and at least 64°F at all other hours. See 105 C.M.R. 410.201 (formerly 410.200) (State Sanitary Code).

G.L. c. 111, \u00a7 127A.proposition: Adequate heat during the heating season is a basic service and requirement under the State Sanitary Code. See 105 C.M.R. 410.201; see also G.L. c. 111, § 127A (authorizing minimum standards for habitability); *Hemingway v. Commonwealth*, 373 Mass. 184, 191–196 (1977) (recognizing habitability standards and tenant protections).

G.L. c. 239, \u00a7 8A.proposition: Defendant, as landlord, had a duty to maintain the Premises, including the heating system, in a condition that complied with applicable health and safety codes and did not unreasonably interfere with Plaintiff’s use and enjoyment of her home. See *Hemingway v. Commonwealth*, 373 Mass. at 192–197; G.L. c. 239, § 8A (recognizing breach of warranty and code violations as defenses and counterclaims); G.L. c. 186, § 14.

G.L. c. 111, \u00a7\u00a7 127A\u2013127L.proposition: Defendant’s conduct also violated public policy expressed in Massachusetts statutes and regulations requiring habitable housing, including G.L. c. 186, § 14; G.L. c. 111, §§ 127A–127L; and 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq. (State Sanitary Code, Minimum Standards of Fitness for Human Habitation).

105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq..proposition: Defendant’s conduct also violated public policy expressed in Massachusetts statutes and regulations requiring habitable housing, including G.L. c. 186, § 14; G.L. c. 111, §§ 127A–127L; and 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq. (State Sanitary Code, Minimum Standards of Fitness for Human Habitation).

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Statutory interest on all monetary awards from the date of the breach and/or date of filing of this Complaint, as permitted by law, including G.L. c. 231, § 6B;

*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (19.proposition: Massachusetts courts have held that “quiet enjoyment” extends beyond mere freedom from physical entry to include freedom from serious and substantial interference with the tenancy. See, e.g., *Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (1977).
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (19.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly treats “quiet enjoyment” as protecting tenants from substantial, serious interferences with use and habitability, not just from physical entry. The court affirms that the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment is breached where noise and disturbances—here, from a lounge—are a natural and probable consequence of the landlord’s conduct or omissions and render the premises not reasonably habitable, thereby constituting constructive eviction. This aligns with the proposition that quiet enjoyment extends beyond physical invasion to serious interference with tenancy.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (19.relevant_excerpt: “The judge found that the tenants were ‘very substantially deprived’ of quiet enjoyment of their leased premises ‘for a substantial time’… He ruled that the tenants’ implied warranty of quiet enjoyment was violated by late evening and early morning music and disturbances coming from nearby premises which the landlords leased to others for use as a bar or cocktail lounge… Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did… they should not be entitled to collect rent for residential premises which were not reasonably habitable.”

*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847, 850.proposition: A landlord’s failure to maintain an apartment in compliance with the State Sanitary Code may constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment when the conditions substantially interfere with the tenant’s use of the premises. See *Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847, 850–852 (1997); *Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas*, 417 Mass. 782, 790–791 (1994).
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847, 850.support_reasoning: The case does discuss G.L. c. 186, § 14 and confirms that negligent failure to repair known defects can violate the covenant of quiet enjoyment, but it does so by citing other cases (including State Sanitary Code cases) and by clarifying that some degree of landlord fault is required. Al‑Ziab itself concerns whether strict liability under the lead paint statute automatically creates a § 14 violation, and the court holds that it does not. It does not specifically address State Sanitary Code noncompliance as such, so it is not direct authority for the stated proposition, though Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas is.
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847, 850.relevant_excerpt: “We noted that a landlord’s failure ‘to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.’ See Cruz, supra at 789, citing Simon v. Solomon, supra at 103 (failure to control floods in tenant’s apartment); Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761 (1979) (failure to repair leaky roof); Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959, 960 (1985) (failure to bring apartment into habitable condition and keep it so).”

*Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas*, 417 Mass. 78.proposition: A landlord’s failure to maintain an apartment in compliance with the State Sanitary Code may constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment when the conditions substantially interfere with the tenant’s use of the premises. See *Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847, 850–852 (1997); *Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas*, 417 Mass. 782, 790–791 (1994).
*Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas*, 417 Mass. 78.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely holds that a landlord’s failure to correct serious State Sanitary, building, and fire code violations—after notice and where the consequences were foreseeable—constitutes a violation of G.L. c. 186, § 14 (the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment) because such failures substantially impaired the value and use of the leased premises as a dwelling. The court emphasizes that the landlord’s omissions, not its intent, control, and it applies § 14 on facts involving severe habitability defects, thereby directly supporting the proposition that sanitary code noncompliance can amount to a breach of quiet enjoyment when it substantially interferes with the tenant’s use.
*Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas*, 417 Mass. 78.relevant_excerpt: “Decisions from this court and from the Appeals Court clearly support the imposition of civil liability under § 14 in circumstances like those present in this case. In Ianello v. Court Management Corp., 400 Mass. 321, 323 (1987), it was said that a landlord violates § 14 when his acts or omissions impair the value of the leased premises. … Cruz Management had notice of numerous sanitary, building and fire code violations in the apartment… On the facts found by the judge a violation of § 14 has been shown.”

*Hemingway v. Commonwealth*, 373 Mass. 1.proposition: Adequate heat during the heating season is a basic service and requirement under the State Sanitary Code. See 105 C.M.R. 410.201; see also G.L. c. 111, § 127A (authorizing minimum standards for habitability); *Hemingway v. Commonwealth*, 373 Mass. 184, 191–196 (1977) (recognizing habitability standards and tenant protections).
*Hemingway v. Commonwealth*, 373 Mass. 1.case_name: Secretary of the Commonwealth v. City Clerk of Lowell
*Hemingway v. Commonwealth*, 373 Mass. 1.support_reasoning: The provided text is from a dissent in a name‑change/vital records case and does not concern landlord‑tenant law, habitability, heat, or the State Sanitary Code. It neither cites G.L. c. 111, § 127A nor discusses minimum standards for habitability or heat as a basic service. Accordingly, this opinion excerpt does not support the proposition regarding adequate heat during the heating season as a basic habitability requirement.
*Hemingway v. Commonwealth*, 373 Mass. 1.relevant_excerpt: An examination of the entire statutory scheme on vital records establishes beyond question that the Legislature intended that the vital records show more than the fact that on a certain date and at a certain place a person was born, married, or died. The clear emphasis of the legislation is on the requirement of a record containing accurate information from which it can be determined who was born, married, or died.

*Lin v. Lowell Hous. Auth.*, 103 Mass. A.raw_text: *Lin v. Lowell Hous. Auth.*, 103 Mass. App. Ct. 1, 5–7 (2023)
*Lin v. Lowell Hous. Auth.*, 103 Mass. A.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a condition of inadequate heat in violation of the State Sanitary Code can support a claim for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See *Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas*, 417 Mass. at 790–791; *Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. at 850–853; *Lin v. Lowell Hous. Auth.*, 103 Mass. App. Ct. 1, 5–7 (2023) (habitability and interference with use).

*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.raw_text: *Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Mass. 273 (1994)
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.proposition: Massachusetts courts consistently enforce the covenant of quiet enjoyment in circumstances where a landlord’s failure to maintain habitable conditions or essential services materially interferes with a tenant’s use and enjoyment of the premises. See, e.g., *Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (1977); *Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (1997); *Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas*, 417 Mass. 782 (1994); *Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Mass. 273 (1994); *Jablonski v. Casey*, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 744 (2005); *Lin v. Lowell Hous. Auth.*, 103 Mass. App. Ct. 1 (2023).
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion directly applies and enforces the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment (G.L. c. 186, § 14) where conditions in the housing development—pervasive drug activity and resulting fear and loss of use of common areas—seriously interfered with tenants’ use and enjoyment of the premises, based on the landlord’s omissions. The SJC holds that such circumstances may constitute a breach and reverses summary judgment, sending the quiet enjoyment claim to trial. Although the case involves criminal activity rather than classic ‘habitable condition’ defects, it clearly affirms that substantial interference with tenants’ use and enjoyment due to the landlord’s failure to act can violate the covenant.
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy — acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leasehold… In this case, we have no doubt that, if the plaintiffs truly are unable to use the common areas of the development… then the situation constitutes a serious interference with their quiet enjoyment and substantially impairs the character of the leased premises… if the defendant has failed to take any measures… then the defendant may be liable for a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

*Jablonski v. Casey*, 64 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Massachusetts courts consistently enforce the covenant of quiet enjoyment in circumstances where a landlord’s failure to maintain habitable conditions or essential services materially interferes with a tenant’s use and enjoyment of the premises. See, e.g., *Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (1977); *Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (1997); *Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas*, 417 Mass. 782 (1994); *Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Mass. 273 (1994); *Jablonski v. Casey*, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 744 (2005); *Lin v. Lowell Hous. Auth.*, 103 Mass. App. Ct. 1 (2023).
*Jablonski v. Casey*, 64 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion does discuss the covenant of quiet enjoyment and recites the general rule that it protects tenants from serious interference with their tenancy when the landlord, with notice, fails to act. However, the court ultimately finds no breach and “no evidence” of interference with quiet enjoyment under the facts presented. Thus, Jablonski is not an example of Massachusetts courts enforcing the covenant in the presence of material interference; it instead affirms a finding of no violation, so it does not support the proposition as phrased.
*Jablonski v. Casey*, 64 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “Casey counterclaimed that York breached her covenant of quiet enjoyment. Similar to the warranty of habitability, during the rental of any residential premises, there exists an implied covenant and a statutory right of quiet enjoyment. … We have interpreted this obligation to mean that the covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant from serious interference with her tenancy. … Here, York acted immediately upon being notified by Casey of the defective conditions… The trial judge did not err in denying the requested ruling of law that a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment had occurred. We see no evidence in the record before us of interference with Casey’s quiet enjoyment of the premises.”
